title: DealBook Briefing: Peter Thiel Accuses Google of Arming China (Again)
summary: The tech billionaire argues that the company is selling an advanced military technology, artificial intelligence, to America’s main rival.

title: Bad Times in Tech? Not if You’re a Start-Up Serving Other Start-Ups
summary: Meet the two Stanford dropouts, both 23, who run Brex, which provides charge cards to start-ups. Its growth is a sign of Silicon Valley’s unflagging exuberance.

title: DealBook Briefing: Corporate America Considers Its Role in Gun Violence
summary: Two new shootings have forced some businesses to reflect on what they can do.

title: Senators Urge Google to Give Temporary Workers Full-Time Status
summary: Temps and contractors outnumber permanent employees at the company, allowing it to maintain labor flexibility and save money.

title: Legal Shield for Websites Rattles Under Onslaught of Hate Speech
summary: Section 230, from a 1996 federal law, was meant to protect young internet companies from liability. Now lawmakers are threatening to change it.

title: DealBook Briefing: How Walmart Could Take a Stand on Guns
summary: The company could help fix a system that is clearly broken, to solve a crisis whose costs are measured in lives, our columnist writes.

title: DealBook Briefing: China vs. U.S. Could Be a Long, Slow Grind
summary: Its economy struggling, China may try to inflict maximum political damage, even hoping that a prolonged trade war could derail President Trump’s re-election campaign.

title: Tech Meets Health Care, Sometimes Shakily
summary: Katie Thomas, who covers health care, has chronicled how the technology disruption in her field has raised questions that are still unanswered.

title: FedEx Ends Amazon’s U.S. Ground Deliveries as Retailer Rises as Rival
summary: The move came two months after the cargo delivery giant said it was ending express shipping for the online retailer.

title: U.S. Moves to Ban Huawei From Government Contracts
summary: The prohibition was mandated by Congress as part of a broader defense bill signed into law last year.

title: The Secret History of ‘Easter Eggs’
summary: Yes, Google, Tesla, Amazon and others are still hiding quirky software surprises in their products, mostly to give you a chuckle.

title: Facebook Said to Be in Talks With Publishers on News Effort
summary: The social network is pitching an initiative to license articles from some of the largest American news publishers for its mobile app, according to people with knowledge of the discussions.

title: Huawei Unveils Harmony, Its Answer to Android, in Survival Bid
summary: The fast-growing Chinese company, blocked by the Trump administration from working with Google, announced plans for its own mobile operating system.

title: DealBook Briefing: China’s Potent Arsenal for Trade Retaliation
summary: The wide variety of options open to Beijing for retaliation in the latest wave of trade and currency tensions have begun to emerge.

title: The Week in Tech: How Does 8chan Whack-a-Mole End?
summary: Efforts to take a controversial website offline have been complex and divisive. But with any luck, they may also be galvanizing.

title: Russia Opens Antitrust Inquiry Into App Restriction at Apple
summary: Russian officials are investigating Apple’s moves to remove parental control apps from its App Store shortly after it released a competing service.

title: A Financier’s End, and Uber Hits the Skids
summary: Also: Barneys files for bankruptcy, and more of the week’s top stories in business and tech.

title: The Phony Patriots of Silicon Valley
summary: Top tech companies are rallying around the flag. How opportunistic of them.

title: Ads Pitching CBD as a Cure-All Are Everywhere. Oversight Hasn’t Kept Up.
summary: “Basically nobody” is overseeing the quality of the many cannabidiol products that have proliferated, one researcher said. The F.D.A. says it is doing everything it can.

title: DealBook Briefing: What Did Jeffrey Epstein Know?
summary: The deceased financier talked to a Times journalist last year about young women and secrets he claimed to hold about the powerful people.

title: If Only These Walls (and Bookcases) Could Talk
summary: Secret rooms have appeared throughout history, in medieval castles and Prohibition-era speakeasies. Now they’re popping up in workplaces.

title: I Shared My Phone Number. I Learned I Shouldn’t Have.
summary: Our personal tech columnist asked security researchers what they could find out about him from just his cellphone number. Quite a lot, it turns out.

title: They Supply the Garage, You Bring the Elbow Grease
summary: My Mechanics Place and similar businesses provide the bay, the lift and some tools, and ambitious do-it-yourselfers take care of the rest.

title: Wells Fargo Closed Their Accounts, but the Fees Continued to Mount
summary: When the bank closes customers’ accounts, it doesn’t always mean money stops going out. That can leave customers with hefty overdraft charges.

title: A.I. Is Learning From Humans. Many Humans.
summary: Artificial intelligence is being taught by thousands of office workers around the world. It is not exactly futuristic work.

title: Director of M.I.T. Media Lab Apologizes for Ties to Jeffrey Epstein
summary: Joichi Ito, a member of The New York Times Company board, accepted donations to M.I.T. and investment money for outside funds from the financier.

title: China Pressures Business Over Hong Kong. Workers Get Caught in the Middle.
summary: Beijing wants global companies to back its power over the city, even as their workers join protests calling for greater say in the fate of their home.

title: To Power A.I., Start-Up Creates a Giant Computer Chip
summary: The chip could improve how quickly artificial intelligence systems can learn tasks. But its complexity and size (as big as a plate) could be a challenge.

title: State Attorneys General Said to Be Near Formal Investigation of Tech Companies
summary: Their bipartisan effort comes after a smaller group of the state representatives met last month with antitrust officials at the Justice Department.

title: In New Facebook Effort, Humans Will Help Curate Your News Stories
summary: A news section inside Facebook’s mobile app will be run by journalists and not just algorithms, the company said.

title: DealBook Briefing: C.E.O.s Look Beyond Their Shareholders
summary: The Business Roundtable said companies should also invest in their employees, protect the environment and deal fairly with suppliers — a sign that shareholder democracy hasn’t worked.

title: How Should Big Tech Be Reined In? Here Are 4 Prominent Ideas
summary: Some critics of the industry want to see the businesses broken up. Others would like to strengthen regulation of Silicon Valley. And there are shades of gray.

title: Hi, Alexa. How Do I Stop You From Listening In On Me?
summary: Humans help train artificial intelligence, so someone may be listening to what you tell Siri, Google Assistant or Alexa. Here’s what to do if you have a problem with that.

title: DealBook Briefing: Trump’s Big Economic Headache
summary: As the economy softens, the president’s early attempts to supercharge it are faltering or maybe even less effective than first thought. That could be a problem next year.

title: YouTube Disables 210 Channels That Spread Disinformation About Hong Kong Protests
summary: Days after Facebook and Twitter cracked down on China-backed accounts that were spreading such disinformation, YouTube did the same.

title: DealBook Briefing: Could This Weekend Bring Relief to the Global Economy?
summary: Central bankers are looking to political leaders to help keep the world’s prosperity going. They might be waiting awhile.

title: The Week in Tech: Facebook’s First Step Toward Treating Our Data Better
summary: The social network’s latest privacy feature at least lets us imagine how we could better control our data in the future.

title: Google Tries to Corral Its Staff After Ugly Internal Debates
summary: The tech company, telling its employees to “stop disrupting the workday,” issued new workplace rules designed to rein in its freewheeling culture.

title: Lawsuit Over Computer Chips Invokes Trade War With China
summary: Globalfoundries has accused T.S.M.C., a competitor in Taiwan, of infringing on 16 patents in a suit that could also affect companies like Apple and Google.

title: The Baroness Fighting to Protect Children Online
summary: Beeban Kidron says tech giants exert too much leverage over young users and has pushed laws to change that. “It’s little Timmy in his bedroom versus Mark Zuckerberg in his Valley,” she said.

title: Former Star Google and Uber Engineer Charged With Theft of Trade Secrets
summary: Anthony Levandowski, one of Silicon Valley’s foremost technologists on autonomous cars, was charged with theft and attempted theft of trade secrets from Google.

title: The Joys of Being a Late Tech Adopter
summary: New-gadget season is almost here, but our columnist has concluded, after testing hundreds of gizmos over the years, that it pays to wait.

title: DealBook Briefing: Can Two Tobacco Giants Save Themselves by Merging?
summary: Altria and Philip Morris International are in talks to recombine as they confront slowing cigarette sales and competition from e-cigarettes.

title: When Children Use Technology, Let Common Sense Prevail
summary: All things in moderation is a good way to think about it, says Jessica Grose, the editor of NYT Parenting.

title: DealBook Briefing: Bond Investors Are Making a Killing
summary: Global gloom has driven investors out of the stock market and toward the traditional haven of bonds. And they’re doing great.

title: Founders of Successful Tech Companies Are Mostly Middle-Aged
summary: Some of tech’s biggest names had founders in their teens. But new research shows that for fast-growing start-ups in the U.S., the average age was 45.

title: DealBook Briefing: Could We Talk Ourselves Into Recession?
summary: Some people worry that chatter about a downturn could spook consumers and lead to a damaging reduction in spending.

title: The Week in Tech: Are You Ready for Facebook’s Future?
summary: We got a glimpse of what the social network’s privacy-first focus might look like in practice. You may not love it.

title: Twitter C.E.O. Jack Dorsey’s Account Hacked
summary: Mr. Dorsey’s account began posting racial epithets, profanities and bomb threats on Friday afternoon. A company spokesman confirmed it was hacked.

title: YouTube Said to Be Fined Up to $200 Million for Children’s Privacy Violations
summary: The fine, from the Federal Trade Commission, could have significant repercussions for other social media platforms that are popular with children.

title: The Week in Business: A Breakthrough Ruling on Opioids
summary: The U.K. is convulsing over Boris Johnson's Brexit maneuver, and Wall Street will be squinting at two start-ups' unprofitable business models.

title: The Week in Business: A Breakthrough Ruling on Opioids
summary: The U.K. is convulsing over Boris Johnson's Brexit maneuver, and Wall Street will be squinting at two start-ups' unprofitable business models.
